article.title: Prolonged Exposure to Particulate Chromate Inhibits RAD51 Nuclear Import Mediator Proteins

funding.text: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

article.abstract: Particulate hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) is a human lung carcinogen and a human health concern. The induction of structural chromosome instability is considered to be a driving mechanism of Cr(VI)-induced carcinogenesis.

sections.introduction: Particulate hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) is an established human lung carcinogen (IARC, 1990).
sections.methods: DMEM and Hamâ€™s F12 50:50 mixture and GlutaGRO (L-alanyl-L- glutamine solution) were purchaed from Mediatech Inc (Herndon, VA).
sections.results: We have previously shown RAD51C function, represented by RAD51C foci formation, is active after acute Cr(VI) exposure, but inhibited by prolonged exposure (Browning et al., 2016).
sections.discussion: The inhibition of the high fidelity DNA repair pathway, homologous recombination, allows for the development of Cr(VI)-induced structural chromosome instability (Browning et al., 2016; Qin et al., 2014; Stackpole et al., 2007).

article.insights_summary: Prolonged exposure to particulate chromate inhibits RAD51 nuclear import mediator proteins, leading to cytoplasmic accumulation of RAD51.
